bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.title: On, on the Same, Ye Jocund Twain!
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

lg.l: On, on the same, ye jocund Twain!
My life and recitative, Continuing birth, youth, mid-age years
Fitful as motley tongues of flame inseperably twined and merged in one—combining all,
My single soul—aims, confirmations, failures, joys—nor single soul in these alone,
I chant my nation's crucial stage (America's haply humanity's)—the trial great, the victory great,
A strange ecclaircissementéclaircissement of all the masses, past the eastern world, the ancient, medieval;
Here, here, from wanderings, strayings, [gap] wars, defeats—here at the west a voice triumphant—justifying all,
A gladsome healing cry—a song for once of utmost of pride and satisfaction;
I chant, from it the race, the common bulk, the general average horde (the best no sooner than the worst)—and now I chant old age,
(My verses, written first for earl forenoon life, and for the summer's, autumn's spread,
I pass to snow-white hairs the same, and give to pulses winter cool'd the same;)
As here here in carelesss trill, chant, I and my recitatives myself, with faith and love,
Wafteding to other work, to unknown joys,songs, conditions,
On, on, ye jocund twain! continues on, the same!
